lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can practise pronouncing words with the “tch”, “ch”, and “dg” sounds accurately.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Say: “watch, catch, bridge, match.” Students repeat. Write the endings (-tch, -ch, -dg) on the board. Students sort example words by sound.
stretchStrategies: Animal Fact Cards – In groups, students design a trading card for one of the animals from the reading. Include: picture, appearance features, what it eats, where it lives. Share cards with another group and ask Qs (“What does it look like?”). Links reading + science + vocab.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read a short text about lost property on the London Underground and find key details such as objects and numbers.
supportStrategies: (Reading) Read the text together. Ask: “What did people lose?” Students underline key nouns and numbers (e.g., 10 watches, 5 keys).
stretchStrategies: Animal Fact Cards – In groups, students design a trading card for one of the animals from the reading. Include: picture, appearance features, what it eats, where it lives. Share cards with another group and ask Qs (“What does it look like?”). Links reading + science + vocab.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can learn interesting facts about what people lose on the London Underground.
supportStrategies: (Social Studies) Ask: “What do people lose in Vietnam?” Students list items and compare with the UK list. Tally as a class.

items: The -ing is often forgotten. Vietnamese does not have different forms of the same verb. I like eat rice.
VYL: many words starting in sibilants prove extremely difficult (shirt, shorts, socks, shoes). Plurals for singular items (trousers, shorts)
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]
Bạn muốn ăn gì? >> you want to eat what? [what do you want to eat?]
This is extremely difficult to master, especially combined with do-support.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
